title: Coast: the shore of a sea or ocean
author: Eduardo Omine

Ignacio, LOL!
English: seashore.

Dutch: kust   
Welsh: arfordir
C�sta (Irish Gaelic, thingy over 'o' know as a fada.)

is it spelled 'fada' and not 'fatha' which is how it more said???   
   
ie. see, oh fatha, esss, tee , ay..

In Russian it's 'b **e** reg'.   
   
That is, in caps that would spell 0411 0415 0420 0415 0413, and in l.c. 0431 0435 0440 0435 0433.   
   
Of course, there are other words too, but 'bereg'   
sounds the snappiest, and looks very elegant, very rhythmic, in both upper and lower case.

The most common Latin word would be _ora_ which means an edge or boundary, but which is applied to the coast also.   
   
Here are a few from dictionaries that I am fairly sure of:   
   
In Indonesian it is _pantai._   
   
In Dutch it is _kust_, while in Afrikaans it is _kus._   
   
My favourite may be the Tagalog (Philippines) word _pampang._   
   
I think in Swahili it is _pwani_, but can't guarantee that.

Armenian: ap (ayb,piwr in Unicode spelling)   
It also means the palm of the hand.   
   
Seashore: dzovap (the "dz" one sound)   
Lake shore: ljap   
River shore: kedap (getap in Eastern pronunciation)   
   
hhp

In Arabic it's shatt (with a doubled deep "t" - tah in Unicode spelling).   
Unless that means gulf, I'm not sure - sorry.   
   
hhp

Vincent wrote:   
"is it spelled 'fada' and not 'fatha' which is how it more said???"   
   
Vincent, the spelling is fada, it's the letter sounds that are different in Gaelic.
breton -\> aod

Arabic: Shatt is spoken Arabic for beach (the sand or rock bit), Shatti' is the formal Arabic. Coast would be sahil (FEB3 FE8E FEA3 FEDE, h being the undotted jim lookalike and not the heh). Gulf would be khaleej.   
   
Hope this helps.
